prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO(3-2) RA<80
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: CO(3-2) observations for sources with RA < 80 deg

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We use the Olofsson (2008) relation (Eq. 7) to compute the flux of the CO(3-2) line for all of our targets. The flux level is in the range 0.05--0.92 Jy, corresponding to a >5-sigma detection at peak flux for all sources (median: \approx 16-sigma). Similarly, our 860 $\mu$m continuum flux estimates (0.41--2.6 mJy) would result in >~5-sigma detections (median: \approx 9-sigma). The continuum expected for stars with disks is much higher (~10x; see right panel in Fig. 1).

We use one spectral window (Band 7) to observe the CO (3-2) line with a spectral resolution of 0.4 km/s, which is needed to trace the shape of the CO profile. The remaining three spectral windows are used for continuum flux measurement. We expect that the CO lines will range between 20-30km/s and the chosen frequency resolution (0.4 km/s) is tuned to measure the shape of lines of this typical width at best signal-to-noise.

The CO photodissociation radius determines the extent of the circumstellar envelope; it is a function of the mass-loss rate (MLR), expansion velocity, and CO abundance (Groenewegen et al. 1998). For IRC+10216 (MLR=1.5e-5 Msun/yr, fCO=1.1e-3, L=(1-1.5)x10^4 Lsun), this corresponds to an angular diameter of about 0.5" at 50 kpc. The largest MLR in our sample is 2.3e-4 Msun/yr, which corresponds to about 3-4" for expansion velocity between 10 and 15 km/s. Therefore, a single pointing is sufficient for these observations. The 345 GHz beam of 1" is comparable to the estimated angular sizes; since the sources are barely resolved, single pointing and short integration times should produce good imaging. As we are only interested in the shape of the CO feature and the continuum flux level, these values are adequate for our observations.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO(3-2) RA>=80
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: CO(3-2) observations for sources with RA >= 80 deg

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We use the Olofsson (2008) relation (Eq. 7) to compute the flux of the CO(3-2) line for all our targets. The flux level is in the range 0.05--0.92 Jy, corresponding to a >5-sigma detection at peak flux for all sources (median: \approx 16-sigma). Similarly, our 860 $\mu$m continuum flux estimates (0.41--2.6 mJy) would result in >~5-sigma detections (median: \approx 9-sigma). The continuum expected for stars with disks is much higher (~10x; see right panel in Fig. 1).

We use one spectral window (Band 7) to observe the CO (3-2) line with a spectral resolution of 0.4 km/s, which is needed to trace the shape of the CO profile. The remaining three spectral windows are used for continuum flux measurement. We expect that the CO lines will range between 20-30km/s and the chosen frequency resolution (0.4 km/s) is tuned to measure the shape of lines of this typical width at best signal-to-noise.

The CO photodissociation radius determines the extent of the circumstellar envelope; it is a function of the mass-loss rate (MLR), expansion velocity, and CO abundance (Groenewegen et al. 1998). For IRC+10216 (MLR=1.5e-5 Msun/yr, fCO=1.1e-3, L=(1-1.5)x10^4 Lsun), this corresponds to an angular diameter of about 0.5" at 50 kpc. The largest MLR in our sample is 2.3e-4 Msun/yr, which corresponds to about 3-4" for expansion velocity between 10 and 15 km/s. Therefore, a single pointing is sufficient for these observations. The 345 GHz beam of 1" is comparable to the estimated angular sizes; since the sources are barely resolved, single pointing and short integration times should produce good imaging. As we are only interested in the shape of the CO feature and the continuum flux level, these values are adequate for our observations.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
Dust production and injection into the ISM is a vital process governing galaxy evolution. The origin of ISM dust is highly debated and is varyingly ascribed to formation in dense ISM, injection by supernovae, or formation in evolved low-mass star outflows. There are only a few galaxies where the global dust injection rate can be estimated by analysing individual evolved stars. We have identified all the mass-losing evolved stars in the LMC. However, the most prolific dust producers lie in a region of the mid-IR colour-magnitude space where they are confused with YSOs.
We propose 12CO J(3-2) and 860 um continuum observations at 1" resolution for 10 LMC sources, spanning the range of MIR colours expected for the dustiest carbon stars, to efficiently and uniquely distinguish AGBs ("spherical" outflow sources) from non-outflow sources. As the submm continuum fluxes and CO line profiles of disk-like sources are very distinct, these ALMA observations can make an unambiguous ruling on the nature of the observed sources. If many of these sources are indeed mass-losing AGBs, the GLOBAL LMC injection rate may currently be underestimated by a factor of a few.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: This proposal was originally accepted as part of Cycle 2 (2013.1.01295S) and was ranked in the top 20-40% bin, but no observations have been made as of 2015-04-23. We do not request reobservations.
